Dear Diane Marquess:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
10/30/2023-11/3/2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written
corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date
of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
(3) An agency shall document all of the following in a
child’s record before a change of placement occurs:
(i) That the current foster parent was notified of the
following in writing:
(ii) Of the current foster parent’s rights concerning the
change in placement.
1 of 8 open files of youth in foster care placements did not contain documentation
that all required notifications were made following a placement change.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
(3) An agency shall document all of the following in a
child’s record before a change of placement occurs:
(f) notification to the parents, referral source, lawyer
guardian ad litem, and courts when applicable, of the
change in placement.
1 of 8 open files of youth in foster care placements did not contain documentation
that the caregiver was provided their rights regarding a placement change.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
2

(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy must
include all the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(i) A comprehensive medical examination within 30
calendar days from the date the child entered into out of
home placement, regardless of the date of the last
physical exam.
1 of 8 open files of youth in foster care placements reviewed did not contain
documentation of an initial medical examination.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(2) An agency’s medical and dental care policy must
include all the following:
(e) A dental examination must be completed within 3
months before entry into foster care or an initial dental
examination must be completed not more than 90
calendar days after entry into a foster care out-of-home
placement. A child entering foster care under 1 year of
age must have an initial dental exam within 3 months of
his or her first birthday.
2 of 8 open files of youth in foster care placements did not contain any dental
examination documentation.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
1 of 11 open youth files reviewed contained an initial service plan that was not
completed timely. This represents 1 of 5 initial service plans reviewed.
CPA Rule 400.12505 Supervision
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum
supervision:
(a) Face-to-Face contact between the social service
worker and the youth in independent living at least once
each month at a youth’s place of residence
3

1 of 3 open files of youth living independently did not contain documentation that a
youth was seen in his home one month.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement
(3) The agreement must be signed and dated by the
youth and the social service worker. The agreement
must be reviewed with the youth at least once every
90 calendar days and a copy provided to the youth.
2 of 3 open files of youth living independently did not contain all required
independent living contracts.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/11/2022 Interim, CAP approved 4/20/2022
CPA Rule 400.12604 Orientation
(1) An agency shall provide an orientation for prospective
applicants for adoption before an adoptive application
is provided
3 of 6 adoptive family assessment files reviewed did not meet the requirements
regarding orientation. One was missing documentation that orientation was held and
two contained applications that were signed prior to the orientation occurring.
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a
written adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the
family signing an adoption application and prior to
approving a family for adoption.
1 of 6 adoptive family assessment files reviewed contained an assessment
completed outside of the required timeframe.

FOM 722-06B F AMILY TEAM MEETING
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case
Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan
due date. Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three
business days prior to a planned change of placement or
no later than three business days after an unplanned
placement change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case
closure date or one business day after unplanned court
ordered dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting
Report, is used to capture family demographics, FTM
logistical information, needs, strengths, action steps,
safety concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the FTM.
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for
every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MiSACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business
days of the FTM.
2 of 11 open youth files reviewed did not meet all FTM requirements. One file was
missing required paperwork for FTMs documented to have been held and one file
did not have documentation that all required FTMs were held.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/11/2022 Interim, CAP approved 4/20/2022
11/22/2022 Renewal, CAP Approved 12/12/2022

FOM 722-06H C ASE CONTACTS
CONTACT WITH CHILD'S CAREGIVERS
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face
contact in the caregiver’s home each calendar month. If
there is more than one caregiver, such as a primary and
secondary caregiver, the caseworker must have a face-
to-face contact with the secondary caregiver in the home
at least once each quarter.
First Two Months after Initial Placement or a
Placement Change
The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face
contacts per month with each child in the first two
months following an initial placement or a placement
change.
CHILD IN A PARENTAL PLACEMENT
The contact standards detailed in this section are
required anytime a child is placed with their parent or
legal guardian.
Residential or Institutional Setting
When a child is placed in a residential or institutional
setting, the caseworker must have contact with the case
manager/therapist assigned to the child, as described in
this section.
MiSACWIS Documentation
Caseworkers must identify whether a private meeting, or
safe sleep verification for infants, occurred for each child
participant in the Participant screen within the Social
Work Contact section of MiSACWIS.
2 of 11 open youth files reviewed did not have documentation that quality visit
standard requirements were met during monthly home visits.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/11/2022 Interim, CAP approved 4/20/2022
FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND
S IGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker
6

• Supervisor
• Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are
placed apart
• Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
• Youth ages 14 and older.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court-ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must
check yes or no for the following when signing the
treatment plan:
• I have participated in the development of the
Case Service Plan and the Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
• I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent
Agency Treatment Plan.
• I have been provided a copy of the Case Service
Plan and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to
review, and I will have the opportunity to express
my disagreement with the Case Service Plan and
Parent Agency Treatment Plan when the
information is presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to
sign the treatment plan, the caseworker must identify,
and document actions needed to secure the parent’s
and/or youth’s participation in service planning and
compliance with the treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the
electronic case record within 30 days of the report date.
4 of 11 open youth files reviewed contained PATPs that either did not have all
required signatures or had signatures not obtained timely. This represents 7 of 22
PATPs reviewed.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
11/22/2022 Renewal, CAP Approved 12/12/2022
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Document the adoption worker's efforts to obtain all the needed documentation. If
denials are being written due to lack of information, this must be either due to the
family not providing what is needed or another outside entity delaying information
7

(i.e., fingerprinting, out of state criminal history, etc.) Be sure to document the
worker efforts and progress in detail within the applicable sections of the denial
as opposed to "still gathering this information."
• Medical Passport signature pages are being uploaded in incorrect location under
"appointments" by some staff. Review policy regarding proper upload location.
• Be sure to generate and save updated medical passports once per quarter. The
generate and save function is required to verify the most updated information is
in the medical passport.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• If information required per rule 400.12417 is not documented in the case record
when a case transfers, be sure to document that your agency provided the
information to the family.
• Consider having adoptive families sign a new application following a denial
based on lack of information as opposed to later completing an addendum.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were 2 substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. Both special evaluation regarding maltreatment in care were reviewed and
found to be thorough. One of two reports contained confidential information which
was cited within this inspection report.
There were 2 incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. Both special evaluation regarding corporal punishment were reviewed and
found to be thorough. One of two reports contained confidential information which
was cited within this inspection report.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The one
CAP submitted by the agency was written in response to the 11/22/2022 licensing
renewal inspection report and was approved on 12/12/2022. That CAP addressed
6 violations, 3 which were not repeated during this inspection. Three of the
violations found this year were repeats from the 2022 inspection with one of the
three having been repeated in the last 2 inspections. Two of the violations found
this year were repeats from the 2021 inspection and 8 violations found this year
were not found in the past two inspections.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator identified challenges related to staff turnover and
vacancies requiring supervisor to carry cases, foster home recruitment/retention,
CWLM implementation and adoption completion barriers. Despite these
challenges, the chief administrator described overall success with the
implementation of last year's CAP.
8

Financial Overview
Reviewed annual financial report. No financial concerns were identified.
Staff Interviews
No concerns were identified by staff.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency appears to have adequate space and equipment to perform the
required job functions. The CHRI, closed adoption, and open case files are stored
within lockable cabinets and/or lockable rooms to prevent unauthorized access
and destruction. The files are all maintained within the office, which can only be
accessed through two locked doors.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
No safety concerns were identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
